column1: Looking forward to our arrival on June 30Wondering how the mosquitos situation is at this time of yearAny news of mosquitoes carrying zika,dengue ?CDC issuing a warning to potentially pregnant women(which I definitely am not)but I do seem to be a mosquito magnet We do have west Nile in our area in the summer but not serious yetUsual precautions of spray,coverup esp at dusk avoiding "jungle" ,etc should be helpfulAny news?

I haven't looked it up, but I know some people have gotten Dengue in the PV area. It's not like it's rampant though, it just means it's not impossible. I'm not a magnet so no bites in December. As far as getting very many bites it's going to be the no-see-ums that you have better chances of being a target. I never saw a mosquito in 3 weeks. Just use repellent if you're around a lot of foliage. Some people cover up, but I don't. 3 of us went on a 4 hour hike in the jungle, we used repellent and none of us got bit. If repellent never helps you, then that's another story!

I doubt it the report mentions Central and South America, nothing about North America. The usual over reaction, I'm afraid. 3 cases reported in Mexico and one had travelled from Colombia ! not exactly an epidemic !

Try vitamin B6,9 and 12 or a B complex. It helps. There is a nice smelling cream here in PV that seems to work wonders as well. It is called "Fight The Bite" Available at the Saturday market in old town.

Given the results of this virus on pregnant women or women intending on becoming pregnant I don't find it an over reaction. http://www.vallartadaily.com/living/health/u-s-issues-travel-alert-over-zika-virus-in-mexico/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+VallartaDaily+%28Vallarta+Daily%29

I realize it's not an epidemic just looking for some info like others have given me,not snarky commentsActually Mexico was on the CDC list and this is the first time I've noticed a CDC warning like thisCases in Hawaii, one had travelled to BrazilThanks to others who have some useful info

Everyone has their own comfort level with risks, but personally, due to the extremely low incidence of mosquito borne illness in PV, I am confident with a good conscientious application of bug repellent. If you are hiking through the jungle or visiting a farm....apply protection often, and wear protective clothing.If you avoided every place where there is a bit of risk, you'd never leave home.You are wise to educate yourself and act accordinglyEdited: 4 years ago
Thanks I am widely travelled and not afraid just like to know what's happening where I'm goingAlso finding the whole insect profusion because of climate change interestingThanks for the info

Actually last trip Oct/Nov 2015 I had so many bites from no-see-um that took a few days to develop and then months of infected bites before they were gone.We just got back early this morning (stayed at the Hyatt) within minutes last Saturday After using deep woods off I was bitten by mosquitos (saw them)I woke up the next day with huge welts and tried using my trusted Gelicam not a whole lot of relief (compared to last trip)Tuesday I went into to see Freddie on Olas Atlas and tried to buy more Gelicam he looked at the biggest bites (10 at this point) shook his head and said, no just a few no see ums mostly mosquito bites that were getting infected. He sold me a 2.5 cortisone cream that really helped for a few days. Thursday we went back and I showed him the first bites and 10 more. He said I was far too sweet and the mosquitos loved me. Benadryl helped me sleep at night. I don't usually see the bugs that love me but this trip? At least ten of the twenty bites were mosquitoes

Do the CDC have a warning out about Hawaii ? Really, one case in Chiapas one in Nuevo Leon, since the mosquito is the vector, it would have to bite one of those two people and fly all the way to PV.Better watch out for the cobbles and the uneven pavements than worry unduly about this.

and just found on cdcWhen used as directed on the product label, insect repellents containing DEET, picaridin, and IR3535 are safe for pregnant women. wear light and long sleeve shirt and pants. Further guidelines for using insect repellents are available online (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/page/avoid-bug-bites see below)FOR PROTECTION AGAINST MOSQUITOES ONLY: Products with one of the following active ingredients can also help prevent mosquito bites. Higher percentages of active ingredient provide longer protection.DEETPicaridin (also known as KBR 3023, Bayrepel, and icaridin. Products containing picaridin include Cutter Advanced, Skin So Soft Bug Guard Plus, and Autan [outside the US])Oil of lemon eucalyptus (OLE) or PMD (Products containing OLE include Repel and Off! Botanicals)IR3535 (Products containing IR3535 include Skin So Soft Bug Guard Plus Expedition and SkinSmart)Always follow product directions and reapply as directed.If you are also using sunscreen, apply sunscreen first and insect repellent second.Follow package directions when applying repellent on children. Avoid applying repellent to their hands, eyes, and mouth.Consider using permethrin-treated clothing and gear (such as boots, pants, socks, and tents). You can buy pre-treated clothing and gear or treat them yourself.Treated clothing remains protective after multiple washings. See the product information to find out how long the protection will last.If treating items yourself, follow the product instructions carefully.Do not use permethrin directly on skin.
